It is possible for a sociopath to become aware of their condition and seek help voluntarily, but it is relatively uncommon. This is because the nature of sociopathy often makes it difficult for individuals to recognize and admit that they have a problem.

Sociopaths typically have a reduced capacity for empathy and do not experience emotions such as guilt, remorse, or shame in the same way as people without sociopathy. This can make it difficult for them to recognize that their behavior is harmful or that they are experiencing personal difficulties as a result of their condition. Additionally, sociopaths may struggle with the concept of seeking help, as this may be seen as a sign of weakness or vulnerability.

However, there are cases where sociopaths have voluntarily sought help. This may occur if the individual is experiencing personal distress or is motivated by a desire to improve their relationships or social standing. In some cases, sociopaths may voluntarily seek help if they face legal consequences or other negative consequences as a result of their behavior.

It is important to note that seeking help for sociopathy can be challenging and may not always lead to positive outcomes. Treatment for sociopathy tends to be focused on managing symptoms and improving social functioning rather than curing the underlying condition. Additionally, sociopaths may be resistant to treatment or may use therapy as an opportunity to further manipulate or exploit others.
